data.title: Classic Hollywood Narrative Techniques In Casablanca

data.text:
Casablanca has all the basic structures of a Classical Hollywood film, as indicated with the opening shots. In the first few minutes of the film, few details are told to the audience, explaining that the Germans were talking over Europe, the coming of World War II, and the political refugees fleeing. Lisbon was the common point of exit and there was often no easy way to get there, so many people travelled to Casablanca, in Morocco. In Casablanca, people would do anything to get an exit visas. The narration was beneficial for audience to easily follow and this helped the story to develop.

Due to Casablanca being Classic Hollywood Narrative, the story began in a chronological order. This helped the audience to see the reasons for the occurring …show more content…

A motif can be defined as an aspect that is repeated in a film, which has a significant meaning. Max Steiner was told to use the popular song “As Time Goes by” as a love theme for the two main characters, Rick and Ilsa. During the film, there was a constant repetition of this song, “As Time Goes by.” This song was a dominant motif. In the first scene, Sam plays “As Time Goes by” for Ilsa- Rick’s lover. Rick had requested for him never to play this song. It is safe for the audience to think that the song brings unwanted memories of Ilsa. Rick then hears Sam playing and tells him to stop playing the song. In this scene Rick saw Ilsa. This was the first time he had seen her since abandonment in Paris. He was utterly shock. As Sam plays “As Time Goes by” in the lounge, Rick fades into a flashback when he was in Paris. This was where he met his lover, Ilsa. This was one of Rick’s happiest moment in his life. In this scene, the song as played in a much cheerful way versus it’s original format. This is symbolic of happiness. There was a difference with the song when played in the train station. In this scene, Rick is heart broken when he read a letter from Ilsa telling him that she can never see him again. In this scene, the rain also was falling. This is symbolic of Rick’s sad mood. The motif “As Time Goes by” was present in the final scene. In the finale scene, Rick tells Ilsa to board the plane to leave Casablanca with her husband instead of himself. This was sad as this prevented Rick and Ilsa from being together.
